awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Bridging the Gap from Northern Iberia to Northwest Africa to Reconstruct Atmospheric Dynamics and Hydroclimate for the Last 2,500 Years
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mediterranean region is identified as a climate change hot spot. Recent observations, including increased fire activity in 2017, suggest that aridity in the Iberian Peninsula is already increasing. This multi-institutional team of researchers seeks to provide a spatial and temporal context for on-going and future climatic changes in this region by constructing a 2,500-year-long history of hydroclimate variability from precipitation-sensitive stalagmites formed in caves in central and southern Portugal. Rainfall in Iberia is strongly correlated to the strength of the Azores sub-tropical high-pressure system, and these cave sites lie at its climatological epicenter.  

Specifically, this project aims to bridge the hydroclimate knowledge gap for the last 2,500 years using sub-decadally resolved, multi-proxy stalagmite records (carbon and oxygen stable isotope ratios, trace element abundances, growth laminae, and high precision Uranium/Thorium dating) from cave sites in central and southern Portugal.  Based on measuring, counting and comparing the uppermost Uranium/Thorium age from one stalagmite, these laminae appear to be annual in nature. Resulting data will be combined and evaluated with similarly-resolved hydroclimate-sensitive records from northern Iberia (Spain) and northwest Africa (Morocco), creating a latitudinal transect that will allow spatial and temporal constraints to be placed on the Azores High

This research could also provide a significant spatial bridge between the only existing high-resolution paleo-hydroclimatic reconstructions (northern Morocco and northern Spain) from this zone. Together, these time series will allow for a more comprehensive evaluation of dynamical changes in the regional climate system through time, particularly in the spatial extent and intensity of the Azores High.

The state of the atmospheric circulation in the North Atlantic region during recent millennia, and particularly medieval times, remains the subject of considerable debate in both proxy- and model-based studies.  Of particular interest is the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), an atmospheric dipole between the Iceland low and the Azores high, which is strongly linked to regional inter-annual precipitation variability in Western Europe and northwest Africa through the routing of storms tracks. Dynamics of the NAO and the Azores High are poorly understood prior to the late 19th century, and as a result, the drivers of NAO/Azores High dynamics have not been adequately explored.  An ideal place to address these deficiencies is central and southern Portugal, where few, if any, high-resolution records exist.

The potential Broader Impacts (B.I.) includes the potential to transform the understanding of the nature and drivers of past Iberian hydroclimate variability, and through comparison with model simulations, how it may respond to future anthropogenic forcing. As such, the development and synthesis of these high resolution and precisely dated records will be of value to the broad climate/paleoclimate communities.  All data produced as part of this project will be made publicly available and archived on community websites. The project unites a diverse, internationally recognized team of researchers from major research institutions (Iowa State University, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, University of New Mexico) and liberal arts colleges (Cornell College, Union College) to apply multi-disciplinary approaches to addressing long-term hydroclimate dynamics. This work will involve the training of a PhD student already in residence at Iowa State and at least eight undergraduate researchers in state-of-the-art climate reconstruction and modeling techniques.  A component of data collection in Portugal will involve citizen-based science at a local tourist cave and with regional caving groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Atmospheric pressure differences associated with the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) play a major role in the weather and climate of much of northern Europe. The NAO consists of two dipoles ? the semi-permanent high pressure centered over the Azores islands (Azores High) and the semi-permanent low pressure over Iceland (Icelandic Low). The relative difference between these two dipoles causes substantial variability in temperature and precipitation patterns across Europe. The behavior of the NAO prior to the time when instrumental data collection began (~1860 CE) has been the subject of considerable debate within the scientific community and substantial scientific efforts have investigated its structure through space and time.

To investigate the state of the hydroclimate (both temperature and precipitation) of western Europe and northwestern Africa, we generated hydroclimate records from stalagmites from three caves in western and southern Portugal. At Buraca Gloriosa cave (western Portugal), we developed a hydroclimate record of oxygen and carbon isotope variability from six stalagmites which span the last 9000 years showing a general drying trend coincident with changes in insolation throughout this time.

Additionally, we developed a high-resolution record of oxygen and carbon isotope variability from three stalagmites from Buraca Gloriosa which informs about wet and dry intervals over the last 1200 years. These records of hydroclimate are proxies for precipitation measurements and inform about past climate conditions prior to the instrumental record. The wettest interval in the high-resolution record is 1400-1550 CE with the driest intervals occurring 900-1150 CE and since ~1700 CE. Together these hydroclimate records demonstrate that the last ~150 years are the driest in the last 9000 years.

We used a state-of-the-art climate model (Community Earth Systems Model, CESM, Last Millenium Ensemble, LME) to investigate the role that the Azores High (part of the NAO system) plays in the wet and dry intervals in western Portugal. Some of the driest intervals in the western Portugal stalagmite record correspond to periods when there was an increase in frequency of the Azores High being extremely large (Figure 1), such as the past 150 years. Additional investigation with various simulations of the CESM confirmed that the trend of increasing size of the Azores High over the last 150 years is related to an increase in greenhouse gases (Figure 2).

At the southern Portugal site, we developed an annual time series of oxygen and carbon isotope variability since 700 CE from three stalagmites from two caves (Grutas Ibn Ammar and Companheira Grande caves). The climate history from these stalagmites shows substantial coherence with the western Portugal record (Buraca Gloriosa) and details a fairly dry and variable interval from ~ 900 CE to 1350 CE, followed by a relatively wet interval (1400 to 1700 CE). Since ~1700 CE conditions reflect drying until present day in southern Portugal.

Synthesizing the data generated from this work with other records of past climate from the Iberian Peninsula and northwest Africa has demonstrated that wet and dry time intervals happened across the region. However, important transitions such as the dry to wet interval (1200-1400 CE) were not contemporaneous but transitioned from north to south (Figure 3) consistent with a non-stationary Azores High system.

Broader Impacts

This project developed the first, high-resolution paleoclimate records from Portugal over the last 1200 years and generated the first proxy-model comparison from this region allowing for current and future climate change in the region to be put into perspective. A major outcome of this work has been to reveal the importance of the Azores High system and its impacts on regional hydroclimate. All stalagmite isotope and element data and climate modeling output are publicly available via NOAA Paleoclimate. This project has supported a PhD student, two master?s students, and five undergraduate researchers. Three of the undergraduate researchers have been co-authors on manuscripts from this work. Opportunities for students included advanced isotope and mass spectrometry training and fieldwork experiences. More than twelve conference presentations have resulted from this research and four manuscripts have been published with another paper in preparation. Citizen science has been a critical component of this work with members of a local Portuguese caving group collecting drip water biweekly from the southern Portugal caves and owners of a tourist cave in western Portugal collecting rainwater throughout the project.
